item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by Thomas Mann
item.description: "No man remains quite what he was when he recognizes himself." -- Thomas Mann

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by Jonathan Safran Foer
item.description: "One day you will do things for me that you hate. That is what it means to be family." -- Jonathan Safran Foer

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by Zora Neale Hurston
item.description: "There are years that ask questions and years that answer." -- Zora Neale Hurston

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "The past is never dead. It's not even past." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "Memory believes before knowing remembers. Believes longer than recollects, longer than knowing even wonders." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "When the shadow of the sash appeared on the curtains it was between seven and eight o' clock and then I was in time again, hearing the watch. It was Grandfather's and when Father gave it to me he said I give you the mausoleum of all hope and desire; it's rather excruciating-ly apt that you will use it to gain the reducto absurdum of all human experience which can fit your individual needs no better than it fitted his or his father's. I give it to you not that you may remember time, but that you might forget it now and then for a moment and not spend all your breath trying to conquer it. Because no battle is ever won he said. They are not even fought. The field only reveals to man his own folly and despair, and victory is an illusion of philosophers and fools." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "How do our lives ravel out into the no-wind, no-sound, the weary gestures wearily recapitulant: echoes of old compulsions with no-hand on no-string: in sunset we fall into furious attitudes, dead gestures of dolls." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "I decline to accept the end of man... I refuse to accept this. I believe that man will not merely endure: he will prevail. He is immortal, not because he alone among the creatures has an inexhaustible voice, but because he has a soul, a spirit capable of compassion and sacrifice and endurance. The poet's, the writer's, duty is to write about these things. It is his privilege to help man endure by lifting his heart, by reminding him of the courage and honor and hope and pride and compassion and pity and sacrifice which have been the glory of his past. The poet's voice need not merely be the record of man, it can be one of the props, the pillars to help him endure and prevail." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by William C. Faulkner
item.description: "How often have I lain beneath rain on a strange roof, thinking of home." -- William C. Faulkner

item.title: Kerilynn add a quote by Norman Maclean
item.description: "All there is to thinking is seeing something noticeable which makes you see something you weren't noticing which makes you see something that isn't even visible." -- Norman Maclean
